awd_titl_txt: IDBR Type A: Miniaturized Two-photon Microscopy for Deep Brain Imaging: An Integrated Circuit Design Using Electrowetting Optics
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of Colorado to do deep brain imaging using a novel miniature nonlinear microscope. Optical imaging methods combined with fluorescent markers offer the unprecedented ability to study functioning of the complex neural networks in the brain down to the resolution of individual neurons. However, due to light scattering in tissue, over 75% of the brain cannot be studied. Technology that offers the path for high resolution deep brain functional imaging is urgently needed in order to further advance the fundamental understanding of how the brain works. This project will investigate a fiber-optic imaging instrument incorporating adaptable optics. The miniature fiber-optic imaging system implanted minimally-invasively will enable visualization of thousands of neurons deep in the brain. The large volume of imaging is important for understanding the complex interconnections involved in neural networks while access to new regions of the brain will open up study in important areas of the brain that are currently not accessible with other techniques.

The work is interdisciplinary in nature, combining aspects of biology, materials science, physics, and engineering and will provide excellent opportunities for students to broaden their scientific knowledge outside of a specific discipline. The PI's will disseminate the results of their work through teaching and education outreach that includes student groups, undergraduate research opportunity programs and summer programs for under-represented undergraduates. Beyond basic research, results from this project will be used to further the understanding of brain function, advance artificial intelligence, and treat neurological disorders.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Optical imaging methods, combined with fluorescent markers, offer the unprecedented ability to study functioning of the complex neural networks in the brain down to the resolution of individual neurons. This project developed a fiber-optic imaging instrument incorporating adaptable optical components, that was used to study the brain.  The instrument is based on multiphoton microscopy, a nonlinear technique that can provide both structural and chemical information about the sample and can penetrate deep into tissue.   The adaptive optical components were based on the principle of electrowetting, which enables a liquid interface to be controlled electrically.   In particular, we incorporated an electrowetting tunable lens into the microscope. This enabled the collection of 3D images, without any physical adjustment of the instrument. The project also resulted in a compact and low-cost pulsed laser source, optimized for the two-photon microscope.  The laser source was used to image to depths of more than half a millimeter in tissue samples.  The miniature fiber-optic imaging system was implanted in a minimally-invasively manner, and enabled the visualization of neural activity in awake, behaving animals.    Additionally, the PIs have disseminated their work through scientific conferences and journal publications, undergraduate research opportunity programs, summer programs for under-represented undergraduates, and K-12 outreach programs.


Last Modified: 07/25/2019
Modified by: Juliet T Gopinath

The instrument is based on multiphoton microscopy, a nonlinear  technique that can provide both structural and chemical information  about the sample and can penetrate deep into tissue.   The adaptive optical components were based on the principle of  electrowetting, which enables a liquid interface to be controlled  electrically.   In particular, we incorporated an electrowetting tunable lens  into the microscope. This enabled the collection of 3D images, without  any physical adjustment of the instrument. The project also resulted in a  compact and low-cost pulsed laser source, optimized  for the two-photon microscope.  The laser source was used to image to depths of more than half a millimeter in tissue samples.  The miniature fiber-optic imaging system was implanted in a  minimally-invasively manner, and enabled the visualization of neural  activity in awake, behaving animals.
